posts.cooked: This season faced many challenges thanks to these tips, making it difficult to consistently tighten them. How can these tips be tightened?

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked: We use a hydraulic wire crimper to crimp the terminals/lugs on 6awg and 4awg wires. This is the one we currently use available here.

link_counts.title: AMZCNC 12 Ton Hydraulic Wire Crimper Battery Cable Lug Terminal Crimping Tool w/ 10 Dies (8AWG~4/0AWG Crimping Tool) - Amazon.com

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: On the battery terminal to battery cable connection you use a bolted joint. Most bolted joints will do if you do not carry the battery by the cables and handle your batteries with care. If you are passionate about battery connections or prefer 1-tool/1-handed installation these products are a common recommendation.

link_counts.title: QTY 2 - Grasshopper Nut for Battery Terminals
Champs 2025 Presentation- Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance - Friday 10am

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked: One caution, the linked tool and all similar low-cost tools have dies sized for metric wire instead of AWG. The listing mentions 10mm² and 16mm² dies, which correspond to approximately 6AWG and 7.5AWG respectively. Using these sizes causes either an overcrimp or undercrimp in connections, leading to poor electrical contact. I suggest using the Temco TH-0006 tool which offers proper AWG dies at a higher cost but ensures better durability and connection quality.

link_counts.title: Hydraulic Cable Lug Crimper TH0006 V2.0 5 US TON 12 AWG to 00 (2/0) Electrical Terminal Cable Wire Tool Kit with 18 Die Sets - TEMCo Industrial

posts.name: Nate
posts.cooked: We also have been very happy with the power werx crimper which has extended handles and is less awkward to grip.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: Not ideal but if you find yourself with the oversized crimper die and can't afford the more expensive tool you can do what we've done before which is to slide a thin piece of aluminum to crimp along with the terminal.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: We also have been very happy with the power werx crimper. The great thing about this crimper and the other Harbor-Fright and other similar variants can use the corresponding AWG-sized Temco dies. You can get a whole set or order them individually. For the crimper and whole set crimp dies (that’s the same tool as @bbonner posted) visit [this link](https://temcoindustrial.com/hydraulic-cable-lug-crimper-th0006-v2-0-5-us-ton-12-awg-to-00-2-0-electrical-terminal-cable-wire-tool-kit-with-18-die-sets/). For the full set of dies alone go to [this link](https://temcoindustrial.com/temco-th0416-18-piece-die-set-for-the-th0006-hydraulic-cable-lug-crimper/). For the single 6AWG die visit [this link](https://temcoindustrial.com/th0006-single-size-die-set-for-wire-size-6-awg/). They even sell some parts like seals (and more) for those crimpers which surprised me for a sub $50 tool.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Regardless of the connection type, whether it’s a crimped lug, lever nut, push-button, screw terminal, solder, or similar, one must perform a tug test immediately after connecting each wire to check its condition and identify any faulty connections. It’s important to apply just enough force to avoid damaging the smaller wires within the connection.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: One should perform a tug test immediately after connecting each wire to verify the connection is secure and to detect any faulty connections. That is huge! I stress with our electrical team—especially and really all subteams—to have someone check your work. Whether it's crimps, nuts, bolts, or anything else, it's the most cost-effective way to detect, fix, and prevent future problems. While it may feel like an uphill battle, progress is being made on our team especially when issues are caught before they become problems, giving members the satisfaction of preventing a potential field failure.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]

posts.cooked: First of all, thank you very much for your suggestions. As I mentioned, these battery ferrules could come out at any time no matter how much we checked, and if I remember correctly, we had problems in one of our matches because of this. I will consult with my team to buy the products you mentioned, but since I am Turkish, it seems difficult to bring these products to Turkey (in terms of customs and taxes, if the product is 150 dollars, we need to buy it for 300 dollars). Nevertheless, if I can find an awg type plier in Turkey, I will consider it.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: At a previous workplace, assembly workers had one of their coworkers check their work. The QC person checked it again. One last tip is, if there’s a pair of wires, check each individually. I’ve found cases where one wire in a pair was loose, but a tug test on the pair showed they were okay because one was good.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Lever crimpers are more difficult to use and offer fewer size options, but they are significantly cheaper than electricians. This terminal crimping tool is ideal for heavy-duty wire lugs and battery terminals, designed for copper lugs in AWG 8-1/0 sizes. I have one for home use, but I haven’t tested it against competitors yet.

link_counts.title: iCrimp Cable Lug Crimping Tool for Heavy Duty Wire Lugs, Battery Terminal, Copper Lugs AWG 8-1/0 - Amazon.com

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: The quality... the flashing was made so large that I was concerned whether any copper lug material remained at the seam, effectively cold-welding the joint, or if it simply squeezed out the sides.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked: This design appears identical to the original metric one but features rotating dies marked with actual AWG sizes instead of being obviously metric. This raises questions about whether it’s true-to-size or merely re-marked for the U.S. market. Notably, it seems the first inexpensive tool of its kind that isn’t obviously metric upon closer inspection. Additionally, using a die even if incorrectly sized is superior to the makeshift methods I’ve seen employed—such as squishing it in a vice crushing it under an arbor press smashing it with a hammer—and likening Vise-Grips to a crimp tool. 😖

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
The original text has been analyzed and corrected to ensure clarity and proper grammar while preserving its core message. Here is the refined version:

Hammer crimpers are tools I've successfully used for stationary R&D builds in the 0-000 AWP ranges. While not ideal for robots or professional electricians, they do exist and function effectively when used appropriately.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: AutumnPlanet stated that they would consult with their team to purchase the mentioned products but noted difficulty in importing them into Turkey due to customs and tax issues. Specifically, he mentioned that a 150-dollar product would cost 300 dollars in Turkey. He expressed consideration about finding an AWG-type plier locally in Turkey. Additionally, he suggested collaborating with other teams in the same area to obtain the tools collectively, emphasizing that such tools are easy to share and not commonly used.
